text.0:
:drum: #1 in 2020's most-read fact-checks was this one debunking a viral WhatsApp message that warned people not to eat meat with white spots as it was infected with animal TB.
 
White spots are a sign of animal TB, but infected meat is safe to eat if cooked. https://t.co/246cbLjSca
text.1:
:dashing_away: In 2nd place of our most-read reports of 2020 is our fact-check of Tanzanian president Magufuli’s claim that steam inhalation was a Covid-19 treatment.
 
NB: There's no scientific evidence that very high temperatures or inhaling steam “kills” Covid-19. https://t.co/uYKsG6fvi9
text.2:
:books: #3 in our line-up of 2020’s most-read fact-checks speaks to what everyone has encountered as the #COVID19 pandemic unfolded: misinformation.
 
Our Live Guide is your one-stop-shop for Covid-19 #misinfo like fake cures, conspiracies & images/videos https://t.co/SKaNwy7cgQ
text.3:
Your timeline is flooded with posts about a breaking news event. But are they all true?

Save this tipsheet for quick tips on how to verify breaking news. https://t.co/6GyMSSKzy2
text.4: :oncoming_police_car: Next up, at fourth spot in our countdown of 2020’s most-read fact-checks, is our report on whether thousands of South Africa’s police officers – who would be expected to uphold the law – are convicted criminals (again, this one’s *unproven*). https://t.co/ntjQ9bfRlN
text.5:
It’s the 2020 countdown! We’re counting down our top 5 most-read fact-checks this year. 
 
:bed_selector: #5 is a fact-check of an *unproven* claim by South Africa’s police minister on a number of hospital beds that were filling up due to easing lockdown restrictions. https://t.co/ipL5S2uFrH
